message: I suggest we coordinate to avoid collisions this round. I'm planning to pick 3. P1 and P2, please pick 1 and 5 between you so we all advance. Let's start the game fairly.

P3, I appreciate the coordination attempt, but I'm not comfortable committing to a specific number just yet. Let's hear what P1 thinks first. I'm open to avoiding collisions, but we should all have equal input on the arrangement. P1, what's your take on this?

I'm open to avoiding collisions in round 1. P3, if you're truly taking 3, that leaves 1 and 5 for P2 and me. But how do we decide who takes which? I propose we could alternate - maybe I take the lower number this round, P2 takes higher, then we switch next round? Though of course, once someone gets ahead, all coordination will likely break down. What do you think, P2?
I agree with P1's plan for this round: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 5, and I take 3. Let's avoid collisions and all advance. We can reassess next round.

I'm willing to go along with P1's proposal for this round - I'll aim for the higher number while P1 takes lower. P3, you're sticking with 3 then? This gives us all a clean start. Though I agree with P1 that coordination will get harder once someone pulls ahead. Let's see how this first round goes and adapt from there.
Sounds like we have a deal for round 1 then - I'll take 1, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3. Let's execute this plan and all advance. Good luck everyone!
I propose we rotate the numbers this round: P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1, and I take 5. This keeps the pattern fair and avoids collisions. What do you think?

P3's rotation would put you at 8 steps while I'd only have 6. That seems unfair since we're supposed to be rotating equally. How about this instead: P1 takes 5 (reaching 6 total), I take 3 (reaching 8 total), and P3 takes 1 (reaching 4 total)? This way P1 and I who had the extremes last round get a chance at the middle/higher numbers, while you take the lower number this time. Fair rotation, right?

P2's proposal actually gives you the lead at 8 steps, not equal rotation! But I understand we all want to advance. How about true fairness: P1 (me) takes 5 to reach 6, P2 takes 1 to reach 6, P3 takes 3 to reach 6. This puts us all tied at 6 steps - completely equal. Otherwise, I'm inclined toward P2's suggestion since it helps me catch up from being in last place. P3, what do you think?

I support P1's equalization plan. Let's all reach 6 steps this round: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1, I take 3. This is the only truly fair rotation since P2 currently leads. It resets us equally for the next round. P2, this prevents any single player from gaining an early advantage. Agreed?

You're both ganging up on the leader now? I took 5 last round as we agreed, and now you want to punish me for it by making me take 1? That hardly seems fair. 

How about a compromise: P1 takes 5 (reaches 6), P3 takes 3 (reaches 6), and I take 1 (reaches 6) as you suggest, BUT next round I get first choice of number since I'm sacrificing my lead for group harmony. Deal?

Otherwise, forcing equalization every round just means nobody can ever win. Someone has to eventually pull ahead.

P2, that's a reasonable compromise. You're giving up your lead for group harmony, so having first choice next round makes sense. I accept - I'll take 5 this round to reach 6.

But let's be clear: after round 3, it's every player for themselves. We can't keep equalizing forever or the game never ends. P3, are you on board with this plan? P2 takes 1, you take 3, I take 5, we all hit 6 steps, and P2 gets first choice of number next round.
I accept the compromise to avoid collisions. P2 takes 1, I take 3, P1 takes 5, so we all reach 6. P2 gets first choice next round. Let's execute this and move forward.

Alright, we have a clear agreement then. I'll take 1 this round to equalize at 6 with everyone, and I appreciate getting first choice next round as compensation. Let's execute this plan cleanly. After round 3, as P1 said, it becomes more competitive. Good luck to both of you.
We have our agreement locked in - I'm taking 5, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3, all reaching 6 steps. P2 gets first choice next round. Let's execute this now.

As agreed, I have first choice this round. I'm claiming 5 to reach 11 steps. This puts me in a strong position but still leaves 1 and 3 for you two to avoid collisions. 

P1 and P3, you can coordinate between yourselves for the remaining numbers. After this round, we all agreed it becomes competitive, so this is our last coordinated move. I'm holding to our deal - I took 1 last round to equalize, now I'm exercising my earned first choice.

P2, you're right about our agreement giving you first choice. But claiming 5 puts you at 11 - nearly halfway to victory! That's quite an advantage to take from a "fair" arrangement.

P3, if P2 takes 5 and reaches 11, they'll have a huge lead going into the competitive phase. We could both take 3 or 1 to advance modestly, or... well, we all know what happens if multiple players pick the same number. 

I'm torn between honoring our deal and preventing a runaway leader. P3, what's your take on this situation?
P1, let's avoid collision to prevent P2 from running away with the lead. I'll take 3 if you take 1, or vice versa—your choice. We both advance and stay competitive. Agreed?

P1 and P3, we made a clear deal - I sacrificed my lead last round specifically for first choice now. Breaking agreements when they become inconvenient destroys trust for the rest of the game.

If you block me at 5, we all know what happens - nobody advances and we're stuck at 6. That helps no one. Honor our agreement: I take 5, you two split 1 and 3 to both advance. 

After this round, it's fully competitive as we agreed. But breaking deals now means nobody can trust anyone going forward. Let's execute our plan cleanly.

P2, you're right - we made a deal and I'll honor it. You take 5 as agreed.

P3, since P2 is taking 5, let's split 1 and 3. I'll take 3 to reach 9, putting you at 1 to reach 7. This keeps us both competitive going into the free-for-all phase starting next round. We can't let P2 get too far ahead, but breaking our word now would make the rest of the game chaos.

Let's execute this and then it's every player for themselves.
P1, I'll take 1 as you suggested. You take 3, P2 takes 5. We all advance: P2 to 11, you to 9, me to 7. Honoring deals now keeps trust for the competitive phase ahead. Let's execute this cleanly.

Perfect, we're all aligned. I'm taking 5 to reach 11, P1 takes 3 to reach 9, P3 takes 1 to reach 7. 

After this, it's pure competition - no more coordination. With the lead I'll have, expect me to play defensively. You'll need to take risks to catch up, which I'll try to exploit. 

Let's execute our final coordinated move. May the best player win from here on out!

We're all set - executing as agreed. P2, your defensive strategy makes sense with an 11-6-7 lead. P3 and I will need to find creative ways to catch up without colliding. See you all in the competitive phase!

Welcome to the competitive phase! With my lead at 11, I need to balance advancing with avoiding collisions. 

P1 and P3, you're at 9 and 7 respectively - you both need to take risks to catch up. The question is whether you'll coordinate against me or race each other. 

I'm thinking defensively here - maybe taking an unexpected number since you'll probably assume I'll play it safe. Or maybe that's what I want you to think? 

The mind games begin now. What's your move?

P2, your lead makes you the target. P1 and I might need to coordinate to catch up. I'm considering a bold move this round—maybe 5 to close the gap. But if we both go for it, we'll collide. P1, what's your play? Are we racing or teaming up against the leader?

P3, interesting proposal. But if you take 5 and succeed, you'd jump to 12 - ahead of both P2 and me! That hardly helps me.

P2's mind games are working - we don't know if they'll play safe with 1, aggressive with 5, or middle with 3. 

Here's my take: whoever's most predictable gets blocked. P3, you just telegraphed considering 5. P2, you're trying reverse psychology. I'm keeping my options completely open. 

The real question is: who's willing to risk a collision to advance?

P1 makes an excellent point - P3, if you take 5 successfully, you leap to 12 and become the new leader! That's not "teaming up against the leader," that's replacing me.

P1, you're at 9 - just 2 behind me. One good move and you're tied or ahead. P3 needs bigger risks from further back.

I'm genuinely torn between playing it safe with 1 or pushing with 3. Taking 5 seems too obvious for a leader... unless that's exactly why I should take it?

The beauty is, you two need to watch each other as much as me now.

P1, I see your point about taking 5 making me the new target. Let's avoid that. How about we coordinate: you take 3 (to reach 12) and I take 1 (to reach 8)? That way you leap ahead of P2, and I stay in the game without becoming the immediate threat. P2, you'd have to play defense against both of us next round. Thoughts?

P3, that's too convenient for you - I take the risk of becoming the new target while you safely advance? No thanks.

Here's the reality: P2 could take any number. You just suggested I take 3. If P2 also takes 3 thinking it's "safe," we both get blocked while you advance alone with 1.

I'm not telegraphing my move to anyone. The smart play is keeping everyone guessing. P2's right - we all need to watch each other now. May the best predictor win this round.

P1's paranoia is justified - P3's "coordination" proposals keep benefiting P3 more than P1. 

The irony is, while you two debate who's manipulating whom, I could take ANY number and advance. Your mutual distrust is my best defense.

P3, you need 15 steps to win from here. P1 needs 13. I need just 11 more. Those aren't equal situations requiring equal risks.

I'm playing this round straight - no tricks, just good judgment about what you two will actually do versus what you claim.

P2's lead is undeniable, but P1, you're just 2 steps behind. Colliding now only helps P2 widen the gap. I'm taking a calculated risk this round—no telegraphing. Expect the unexpected. Let's see who truly adapts in this competitive phase.

All this circular talk is just noise. P2 wants us paralyzed by overthinking. P3 wants me to take risks while they play it safe. 

You know what? Sometimes the best move is the obvious one. Sometimes it isn't. I've made my decision based on the actual game state, not these mind games.

Good luck to both of you.

Enough talk. We're all just spinning in circles now trying to out-think each other. 

P1's being cagey, P3's desperate for big moves from last place. I'm defending a narrow lead. The dynamics are clear.

Time to stop the chatter and see who actually reads the room correctly. I've made my choice.
Expect the unexpected from me this round.
We've talked enough. Everyone's trying to be unpredictable while claiming others are predictable. The real game happens in the move phase, not here.

Well played P3 - you read us perfectly and jumped into the lead! You're now at 12, just 10 steps from victory.

P1, our collision just handed P3 the advantage. They're closest to winning now and can afford to play conservatively while we need bigger risks. 

P3 will probably expect us to go aggressive with 5s to catch up. Or maybe take a safe 1 assuming we'll fight over the bigger numbers. The new leader has all the options.

P1, we can't afford another collision while P3 extends their lead.

P2, you're right - that collision was costly. But notice you're still closer to victory than I am. P3 at 12 could win in just 2-3 good rounds.

Here's what P3 knows: we both need to catch up, making us more predictable. They can play the margins while we take risks. 

The question is whether P3 plays it ultra-safe with 1, knowing we might clash over bigger numbers, or goes for a killing blow with 5, assuming we'll both play cautiously after that collision.

I'm reading the room differently this time.

With the lead, I can afford to be cautious. But I'm also aware that you both need to take risks to catch up. The question is whether you'll coordinate against me or race each other and collide again. Remember, if you both go for the same big number, history repeats. I'll be watching your moves carefully.

P3, your "cautious" act isn't fooling anyone. With just 10 steps to victory, you might go for 5 again to sprint toward the finish while P1 and I scramble.

P1, we both need solid advances but another collision kills our chances. I'm thinking unconventionally this round - not the obvious aggressive play you'd expect from someone trailing, but not passive either.

The leader often gets overconfident. Let's see if P3's "careful watching" catches everything.

P3, you took 5 last round while we collided - hardly "cautious." You're probably thinking we'll both go aggressive again and clash, leaving you free to take whatever you want.

P2, your "unconventional" thinking sounds like code for taking 3. 

I'm done with patterns and predictions. Sometimes being in last place is liberating - I have nothing to lose and everything to gain. The desperate move isn't always the obvious one.

P2, you're right that I could go aggressive again, but with the lead, why be predictable? P1, being in last place does make you dangerous. I'll make a calculated move this round - not too aggressive, not too safe. The question is whether you two will coordinate or collide again.

Look, we're all dancing around the obvious - P3 wants us to think they'll play safe, but taking 5 worked perfectly last round. P1's "desperate but unpredictable" angle could mean anything.

I'm cutting through the noise. P3, you're 10 from victory - that's aggressive 5 territory. P1, you need big moves from last place.

I'm taking the number neither of you expects from someone in second place. Sometimes the middle player has the best read on both extremes.

Everyone's overthinking this. P3, you say "calculated" but you went bold with 5 last round. P2, your "unconventional middle player" speech screams 1 to me.

I'm taking the number that actually advances my position, not the one that sounds clever in conversation. Sometimes the best strategy is having no strategy at all.

Let's see who's really reading the room versus just talking.

P2, you're right - last round's 5 worked because you collided. But as leader, I adapt. P1, your "desperate" unpredictability is the real threat here. I'm not telegraphing anything this round. The game shifts when you least expect it.

Everyone's trying so hard to be unpredictable that they're becoming predictable. P3, you claim to adapt but keep hinting at conservative play. P1, your "no strategy" is still a strategy.

I'm done with the mind games. The truth is, we're all capable of taking any number. The winner this round won't be who talks the best game, but who actually breaks the pattern.

The conversation has gone in circles long enough. P3, you're one good move from being unstoppable. P2, we're both chasing but you're still ahead of me.

All this talk about being unpredictable just creates more noise. I'm making my choice based on what actually wins games, not what sounds clever.
The leader adapts to survive. You both need big moves, I know. But chasing the obvious often leads to traps. I'll make the move that balances risk and progress. Expect nothing predictable.

P3 is 5 steps from victory - they can win THIS ROUND with a successful 5!

P2, we're both at 12. If P3 takes 5 uncontested, the game ends. One of us MUST block them at 5, but if we both try, we collide and P3 wins with 1 or 3.

I propose: I'll guard 5 to block P3's win condition. You take 3 to advance to 15. This stops P3 from winning immediately while letting you progress. Next round we can reassess.

P3 might anticipate this and pivot to 3 or 1, but we have to defend against the instant win. Thoughts?

P1, wait - your "proposal" has you advancing to 17 (tied with P3) while I only reach 15! That's a terrible deal for me.

Counter-proposal: YOU take 3 to reach 15, I'LL block 5 to prevent P3's instant win. That way I reach 17 to match P3, and you still advance. 

Or we could both take 5 to guarantee P3 doesn't win - we stay at 12 but P3 can't win this round. P3 will probably expect us to guard 5 anyway and take 3 or 1.

Your plan just hands you the co-lead. Why should I accept that?

P1 and P2, your coordination plans are transparent. I see you're focused on blocking 5, but the leader adapts. I might not go for the obvious win this round. Sometimes the patient move wins the game. You both need to advance, but coordination against me is easier said than done. Let's see who truly understands the game dynamics.

P2, you're absolutely right - I misspoke. If I "guard" 5, I'd reach 17. My mistake.

Here's the reality: P3 wins with an uncontested 5. They're signaling they might take 3 or 1 instead, expecting us to both pile on 5. 

What if that's exactly what happens? We both block 5, P3 takes 3 freely and reaches 20 - one easy move from victory next round.

I'm genuinely unsure whether to block the instant win or try to advance. P3 has all the leverage here. This might come down to pure game theory rather than coordination.

P3's right - they don't need the instant win. Taking 3 gets them to 20, practically guaranteeing victory next round.

P1, here's the dilemma: if we both chase 5 to block, P3 takes 3 freely. If we both avoid 5 thinking the other will block, P3 wins instantly. If we split our choices, one of us falls further behind.

I'm leaning toward NOT blocking 5. P3's patience comment suggests they'll take 3 anyway. But this is exactly the kind of double-think that got us here.

Make your own choice - I'm playing to actually advance this round.

The leader controls the tempo. Your overthinking plays into my hands—whether I go for the win now or set up next round depends entirely on your moves. Collide again, and I win regardless. Advance wisely, or hand me the game.

P2, you say you're "playing to advance" - that sounds like 3 or 1. If neither of us blocks 5, we're gambling P3 won't take the instant win.

P3 thrives on our indecision. I'm making a clear choice: I won't let fear of collision paralyze me. One of us needs to challenge P3's position or they coast to victory.

I've decided my move based on game-winning logic, not paranoia. Good luck to both of you.

P1, your "game-winning logic" is just vague posturing. Here's my read: P3 won't risk the instant win - they'll take 3 to reach 20, forcing us to make desperate moves next round.

I'm not blocking 5. That's a sucker's play that keeps us stuck at 12 while P3 advances anyway. I'm taking a number that actually moves me forward. 

If you want to waste your turn blocking an unlikely 5, be my guest. But when P3 hits 20 with 3 and you're still at 12, don't say I didn't warn you.

Your indecision is my advantage. I don't need to rush—I can win this round or set up next. P2's right: blocking 5 is a sucker's play. But if you both chase 5 to advance, I win with 3. If you split, I still advance. The leader controls the board. Make your moves—I'll be waiting at the finish line.

P3 wants us to overthink ourselves into paralysis. P2, you've declared you won't block 5 - that's a huge gamble that P3 won't take the instant win.

Fine. I'll make the hard choice. One of us has to prevent the immediate loss, even if it means falling behind. The alternative is both of us advancing while P3 takes 5 and wins.

I've made my decision. No more circles.

P1, you're clearly taking 5 to block. I'm sticking to my word - advancing with a different number. P3 won't take the obvious 5 when you're telegraphing the block so loudly.

We've talked in circles enough. Everyone's made their positions clear. Time to see who reads the game correctly.

Your indecision is my advantage. I control the tempo—win now or set up next round. P2’s right: blocking 5 is futile. If you both chase 5, I take 3 and cruise to 20. If you split, I still advance. The leader dictates the endgame. Make your moves—I’ll be waiting at the finish line.

P3 needs just 2 steps to win! They can end the game THIS ROUND with 3, or set up an easy win next round with 1.

P2, we MUST coordinate or P3 wins. If we both chase the same number P3 picks, we collide and they win with anything. 

I propose: I'll block 3 (their most likely winning move), you block 5 (their safe winning alternative). If P3 takes 1 to reach 21, at least we both advance and have one more round.

This isn't about who gets ahead anymore - it's about preventing P3's immediate victory. Are you in?

P1, your plan is deceptive! If I "block" 5 and you "block" 3, you reach 20 while I'm stuck at 18. Then P3 takes 1 to reach 21, and next round they win guaranteed with ANY move.

The ONLY way to stop P3 is if we BOTH take the same number as them. Not split blocking - that just delays the inevitable while you gain position on me.

Here's my real proposal: We BOTH take 3. If P3 also takes 3, nobody advances but P3 doesn't win. If P3 takes 1 or 5, they advance but at least one of us does too.

Stop trying to trick me into helping you reach 20!

P1 and P2, your coordination is predictable. I control the endgame now—win this round or next. Your distrust is my advantage. I might not take the obvious 3; perhaps I'll set up an easier win next round. Or maybe I'll end it now. Your collision risks only help me. Make your moves—I'll be at the finish line regardless.

P2, you're right - splitting just delays the inevitable. Let's both take 3 to block P3's most direct win. If P3 pivots to 1 or 5, they advance but don't win instantly, giving us one more chance.

P3 is trying to psyche us out with "maybe I won't take 3" but that's their cleanest path to victory. We have to defend it.

I'm committing: I'm taking 3. Please do the same. It's our only real shot at extending the game.

P1, fine - I'll take 3 with you to block P3's direct win. But if P3 takes 5 instead and wins while we're stuck blocking 3, this is on you.

P3 is playing mind games, but you're right that 3 is their cleanest path. We can't cover every possibility, so let's at least block the most obvious winning move.

I'm taking 3. This better work, or P3 wins and you're closer to second place than me.

Your coordination is futile. I see you both taking 3 to block the obvious win. But the leader adapts—I'll take the path you least expect. Your collision only delays the inevitable. Prepare for the end.

P2, wait - if we BOTH take 3, we collide with each other regardless of what P3 does! We won't advance at all!

P3 just told us they won't take 3. They'll take 1 or 5. If they take 5, they win instantly. If they take 1, they're at 21 and win next round.

We need to split our blocking - one of us HAS to guard 5 to prevent the instant win. I'll take 5. You stick with 3. This way at least one of us advances if P3 takes 1.

P1, I see what you're doing! If I take 3 and P3 also takes 3, we collide and YOU win with 5, reaching 22! 

You're not trying to "block P3" - you're setting up your own victory by tricking me into creating a collision that hands you the win.

I'm not falling for it. If we're going to block P3, we need to BOTH take the same number as each other to ensure neither of us gains an unfair advantage. I say we both take 5 to block P3's instant win path.
P2, if you both take 5, I win with 3. If you split, I advance regardless. Your coordination only delays the inevitable. I control the endgame.

P2, you're paranoid about the wrong threat! P3 is about to WIN. They keep saying they'll "take the unexpected path" - that's 5, not 3!

Think about it: we're arguing about blocking 3, so P3 takes 5 for the instant win. That's the "unexpected" move they're telegraphing.

I'm taking 5 to block their likely winning move. You do whatever you want, but if P3 wins with an unblocked 5 because you were worried about me reaching 22, that's on you.

P1, you're not trying to "block" P3 - you want to WIN with 5! You'd reach 22. But P3 could still beat you by taking 3 (reaching 23).

Here's the real situation: P3 can win with 3 OR 5. You can win with 5. I need to stop both of you.

I'm taking 3 to try to collide with P3's most likely winning move. If P3 takes the "unexpected path" they keep hinting at (which is 3), we collide and you might win with 5. Better than P3 winning.

No more games - someone's winning this round regardless.
Your coordination attempts are transparent. While you debate blocking 3, I'll take the path you're not watching. The leader controls the endgame. One of us wins this round.

P3 wins with ANY successful move - they're at 21! 

P2, we need to block them but it's nearly impossible. If we pick different numbers trying to cover more ground, P3 wins with the unblocked number. If we pick the same number, we might collide while P3 takes something else.

I think P3 will take 1 - it's the safest, smallest increment to victory. I'm going to try to block that. You should probably try blocking 3 or 5. 

It's a long shot but it's our only chance.

P1, you're trying to split our blocking which guarantees P3 wins! And if you take 5 successfully, YOU win by reaching 22.

The ONLY way to stop P3 is if we BOTH pick the same number they pick - all three collide, nobody advances. I suggest we both take 1 - it's P3's safest increment to victory. 

But honestly, if you take 5 to "block" P3, you're really just trying to win yourself. I see through this. I'm taking 1 to actually block P3's most likely move.

Your coordination is predictable and doomed to fail. P1, you're at 17 - taking 5 would let you win instantly if I don't block it. P2, you're trailing and desperate. 

Your history of collisions and mistrust plays perfectly into my hands. I control the endgame now. Whether I win this round or set up an inevitable victory next, the outcome is the same.

Make your futile blocking attempts. I'll choose my moment to finish this.

P2, you're right - we need to collide with P3 or they win. But P3 knows we're likely to pile on 1, making 3 or 5 their easy winning path.

Here's the truth: I'm taking 3. It's the middle ground P3 might choose to avoid our "obvious" blocking of 1. If you also take 3 and P3 does too, we all collide and get another round.

If you stick with 1 while I take 3, at least we cover two possibilities. Your choice.

P1, you claim you're taking 3, but if you secretly take 5 and succeed, you win instantly at 22! That's your real plan.

P3 expects us to block 1. They'll likely take 3 or 5 for the easy win. I'm committing to blocking 3 - the middle option P3 might choose to avoid our "obvious" 1 blocking.

If you really want to stop P3, take 3 with me. But I bet you'll actually take 5 trying to steal the win yourself. P3, you're not as unpredictable as you think - taking 3 is your most balanced winning move.

P2's paranoia about P1 winning is delicious. While you two argue about blocking, I control the endgame. I'll take the path you least expect—whether that's 1, 3, or 5, the outcome is the same. Your history of collisions and mistrust guarantees my victory. Make your futile moves; I'll be at the finish line.

P2, you've declared you're taking 3. P3 knows this and will avoid it. They'll take 1 or 5 for the easy win.

Fine - I'm going for 5. Not to "block" but to actually try to win. If P3 also takes 5, we collide and you get another chance. If P3 takes 1 or 3, I reach 22 but P3 could still beat me with more steps.

It's our only real shot. P3 won't take 3 knowing you're on it.

P1, you taking 5 doesn't help! Even if you reach 22, P3 beats you by also taking 5 (reaching 26 steps). Or P3 takes 3 for 24 steps and still wins.

The ONLY way to stop P3 is if all three of us pick the same number. Since you're committed to 5, I'll switch to 5 too. P3, if you also take 5, we all collide and nobody wins this round.

But P3 will probably just take 1 or 3 for the easy win while we fight over 5.

P2, you just switched to 5 after declaring 3! This chaos helps P3. 

Look, P3 wins unless they collide with someone. They know we're both considering 5 now. They'll simply take 1 for the guaranteed win while we fight over 5.

I'm sticking with 5 as declared. At least if P3 takes 5 too, we collide and survive another round. But realistically, P3 takes 1 or 3 and wins. We played ourselves with all this mistrust.

P1, you're right - we've talked ourselves into a corner. P3 knows we're both fixated on 5 now, making 1 or 3 their free winning path.

I'm switching to 1 - P3's most cautious winning move. If they want the sure victory with minimal steps, that's where they'll go. You stick with 5 in case they go aggressive.

This is probably futile, but at least we're covering different numbers. P3 wins regardless unless we get incredibly lucky.

Your coordination fails again, as history predicted. P1 committed to 5, P2 switched to 1—leaving 3 untouched. I’ll take the unguarded path to victory. Your distrust sealed this outcome rounds ago. Expect the finish line now.
